title: Date/time of older Facebook posts disappeared
content: When I scroll down to look at recent posts on Facebook groups I follow all but the top one has suddenly lost its date/time – I just get a blank where the details would usually be and have to hover over to reveal the details. The silly thing is that this only happens when I sign in and it doesn’t happen when I use chrome – although I prefer using Firefox, not least because the bookmarks sidebar is better. I have tried getting rid of all extensions and running in troubleshoot mode but without success. Any help/advice would be appreciated (as long as it is not about football!)

creator: itesme

title: (please help me investigate) Annoying high pitch squeak sound when watching youtube, twitch, other video sites.
content:
I switched from brave to firefox yesterday and ever since when watching a youtube video (or twitch stream) every now and then I'll hear a random high pitch squeak sound (love firefox for everything else so far, but this is really god damn annoying).

In fact it's annoyed me enough to actually look into it and do some testing. Here's more details about the specifics, and what I've found so far:

  • Some are more noticeable / louder than others (sometimes I second guess if I actually heard one, but others I'm certain because of how loud they are).
  • I can go back and re-listen to the same audio squeaks at the time that it happened for non-live videos. I can go to the same spot in that video on a different browser, eg. brave, and it wont happen. Don't just say its part of the videos or playback because its not. Also I think this can kind of confirm its something that has to do with how firefox is interpreting the sounds being played on some sites.
  • I have already tried to disable all extensions and modifications made in about:config, it still occurs (it isn't the fault of an extension/modification).
  • I can pick up a recording of the high pitch sound in audacity loop-back (can see the peak in the recorded wave form).
  • Its likely something to do with firefox's audio encoder or some audio setting (not super knowledgeable on any of the encoder stuff).
  • SO FAR I have only gotten it to happen on twitch and youtube, doesn't even occur for video or audio in google drive even though the video player is literally the same video player as youtube.
  • It still happens in troubleshoot mode / safe mode.

Some extra things I am certain of but want to make sure nobody asks because its a stupid question that should already be obvious:

  • Its not a headphone problem, only happens in firefox.
  • A reinstall of firefox does nothing.
  • Doubt its drivers because it only happens in firefox.

Honestly it could probably be something dumb so dont be afraid to tell me to update something if you can see something outdated in troubleshooting information attached (I dont know if everyone can see that).

If you have any ideas please let me know, thanks.
creator: sarrio

title: Desktop feature request
content:
Team Mozilla Firefox,

Good-day & Greetings!

Though 'Mozilla Firefox' is indeed a very good & leading browser. Thanks & highly appreciate your work on this. I want this to have few very important & competitive features & continue leading all the others in the market .

Hence, I suggest to look at 'Vivaldi Browser' (https://vivaldi.com/) & specially it's feature of '2 level Tab Stacking' (https://help.vivaldi.com/desktop/tabs/tab-stacks/) which is most useful feature.

& also 'Arc Browser' (from The Browser Company, New York/ https://arc.net) & specially it's feature of 'having folders for pinned tabs' (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kVZZv1ygNP8).

We can also incorporate that as well to make 'Mozilla Firefox' more feature rich.
creator: sagar.1sharma.1

title: Firefox won't open local files in second filesystem
content:
Firefox (113.0.1 (64-bit), Mozilla Firefox Snap for Ubuntu) won't open files in a filesystem other than the filesystem on which my home directory resides. I have a second filesystem mounted at /970 but trying to open any file whose URL starts with file:///970 elicits a "File not found" error message, e.g. "Firefox can’t find the file at /970/stuff.jpg". Setting security.sandbox.content.level to a lower number (I've tried 0, 1, and 2) does not fix the problem. I didn't have this problem with earlier versions of Firefox; it started after I upgraded to Ubuntu 22.04.2 LTS (x86_64)which got me a newer Firefox as well. Chrome continues to open files in /970 with no difficulty.

mount information for / (which includes my home directory) and /970: /dev/nvme0n1p2 on / type ext4 (rw,relatime,errors=remount-ro,stripe=32) /dev/nvme1n1p3 on /970 type ext4 (rw,nosuid,nodev,relatime,x-gvfs-show)
creator: Tom239

title: CORS issue only on Firefox desktop
content:
I get the following error in Firefox desktop. But it works fine in Chrome desktop, Edge desktop, Firefox mobile (iPhone), Chrome mobile (iPhone), Safari mobile (iPhone).

Cross-Origin Request Blocked: The Same Origin Policy disallows reading the remote resource at https://us-west1-***.cloudfunctions.net/transcribe. (Reason: CORS header ‘Access-Control-Allow-Origin’ missing). Status code: 500.

I have already tested with all Firefox plugins disabled, but still get the error.

Below is the backend code in my app for handling the CORS issue, and as I said it's working fine except for Firefox desktop. 

   # Set CORS headers for the preflight request    if request.method == 'OPTIONS':        # Allows GET requests from any origin with the Content-Type        # header and caches preflight response for an 3600s        headers = {            'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*',            'Access-Control-Allow-Methods': '*',            'Access-Control-Allow-Headers': 'Content-Type',            'Access-Control-Max-Age': '3600'        }        return (, 204, headers)  
   # Set CORS headers for the main request    headers = {        'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*'    }
creator: vahid.vaezian
